questions.question: How many minutes on average does it take to mine one Bitcoin block?
questions.hint: Think about Bitcoin's consistent heartbeat - it's a key design feature
questions.explanation: Bitcoin is designed to produce blocks every 10 minutes on average. This timing is maintained through difficulty adjustments every 2,016 blocks.

questions.question: How many blocks occur between Bitcoin difficulty adjustments?
questions.hint: This number also represents the maximum Bitcoin supply in millions
questions.explanation: Every 2,016 blocks (~2 weeks), Bitcoin adjusts mining difficulty. Interestingly, 2100 also appears in the 21 million supply cap.

questions.question: In what year was the Bitcoin Genesis Block mined?
questions.hint: This was during the financial crisis, embedded in the coinbase message
questions.explanation: January 3, 2009. Satoshi embedded 'The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor on brink of second bailout for banks' in the genesis block.

questions.question: How many Bitcoin halvings have occurred as of 2025?
questions.hint: Last one was in 2024
questions.explanation: Halvings occurred in 2012, 2016, 2020, and 2024. The next will be around 2028.

questions.question: How many satoshis are in one Bitcoin?
questions.hint: Think millions, but which kind?
questions.explanation: One Bitcoin equals 100,000,000 satoshis (100 million). A satoshi is the smallest unit of Bitcoin.

questions.question: How many nodes approximately exist on the Bitcoin network (in thousands)?
questions.hint: More than 10, less than 20
questions.explanation: Approximately 15,000-18,000 reachable nodes exist globally. Running a node helps verify the network.

questions.question: How many Bitcoin will ever exist (in millions)?
questions.hint: It's a famous number - the ultimate scarcity
questions.explanation: Only 21 million Bitcoin will ever exist due to the halving schedule and fixed supply cap.

questions.question: What percentage (approximately) of Bitcoin mining uses renewable energy?
questions.hint: More than half - Bitcoin miners chase cheap energy
questions.explanation: Studies estimate 50-60% of Bitcoin mining uses renewable energy, as miners seek the cheapest power sources globally.

questions.question: How many kilowatt-hours (kWh) of renewable energy are needed to earn one SREC (Solar Renewable Energy Credit)?
questions.hint: It's a nice round number in the thousands
questions.explanation: 1,000 kWh (1 MWh) of solar energy generation earns one SREC, which can be sold to utilities meeting renewable portfolio standards.

questions.question: In what year does the Clean Energy DC Omnibus Act aim for 100% renewable energy supply?
questions.hint: It's in the 2030s, and happens to be a power of 2 times a significant Bitcoin number
questions.explanation: The Clean Energy DC Omnibus Act of 2018 sets a goal of 100% renewable electricity by 2032 for the District of Columbia.

questions.question: How many exahashes per second (EH/s) is the Bitcoin network hashrate approximately (as of 2025)?
questions.hint: It's a three-digit number in the hundreds
questions.explanation: Bitcoin's hashrate fluctuates but has been around 350-550 EH/s in 2025, demonstrating massive computational security.

questions.question: What is the typical value in dollars of one SREC in Maryland (as of 2024)?
questions.hint: It's significantly higher than Virginia's $35 - Maryland has aggressive renewable targets
questions.explanation: Maryland SRECs trade around $400-$450 due to the state's aggressive renewable energy requirements, making solar very profitable.

questions.question: How many days approximately does it take for a full Bitcoin difficulty adjustment period?
questions.hint: It's about two weeks...
questions.explanation: With 2,016 blocks at 10 minutes each, difficulty adjustments occur approximately every 14 days (2 weeks).

questions.question: In what year did President Nixon end the Gold Standard?
questions.hint: Early 1970s - a pivotal moment in monetary history
questions.explanation: On August 15, 1971, Nixon closed the gold window, ending Bretton Woods and ushering in the pure fiat era.

questions.question: Approximately how many fiat currencies exist in the world today?
questions.hint: It's one of the orange pill numbers - think about UN member states
questions.explanation: There are approximately 180 fiat currencies globally, all subject to inflation and government control. Bitcoin is one.

questions.question: In what year did Christopher Columbus sail to the Americas?
questions.hint: In fourteen hundred and ninety-two...
questions.explanation: Columbus sailed in 1492, beginning European colonization and eventually the global monetary systems we have today.

questions.question: How many electoral college votes are needed to win the U.S. presidency?
questions.hint: This number represents DMV's political power in the Nobody•Will•Pay distribution
questions.explanation: 270 electoral votes are required to win. This number symbolizes political power and appears throughout the Nobody•Will•Pay project.

questions.question: What is the ideal population size for Plato's perfect city according to 'The Republic'?
questions.hint: It's a highly divisible number - a mathematically 'perfect' choice
questions.explanation: Plato chose 5,040 citizens as ideal because it's highly divisible (1×2×3×4×5×6×7), enabling perfect governance divisions.

questions.question: In what year was gunpowder invented (approximately)?
questions.hint: It's in the 800s - think drum machines and explosives
questions.explanation: Gunpowder was invented around 808 AD in China. Interestingly, 808 also refers to the TR-808 drum machine that revolutionized music.

questions.question: What is the annual inflation target for the Federal Reserve (in percent)?
questions.hint: It's a small single-digit number
questions.explanation: The Fed targets 2% annual inflation, meaning your money loses purchasing power by design. Bitcoin has zero inflation after all are mined.

questions.question: What is the approximate average price in cents per kilowatt-hour (kWh) for electricity in the DMV area?
questions.hint: It's in the 10-20 cent range per kWh
questions.explanation: DMV electricity costs approximately 13-17 cents per kWh, varying by state and provider. This affects home mining profitability.

questions.question: How many basis points (bps) is a 1% change in interest rates?
questions.hint: Basis points are hundredths of a percent
questions.explanation: 100 basis points = 1%. When the Fed raises rates by '25 bps', that's a 0.25% increase.

questions.question: What was the approximate U.S. inflation rate (CPI) peak in 2022 (in percent)?
questions.hint: It was the highest in 40 years - a single digit
questions.explanation: U.S. inflation peaked around 9% in mid-2022, the highest since the early 1980s, driving Bitcoin interest as a hedge.

questions.question: How many cents approximately does a gallon of milk cost in the U.S. (as of 2025)?
questions.hint: Think about your grocery bill - it's in the 300-400 range
questions.explanation: A gallon of milk costs approximately $3.50-$4.20 (350-420 cents), illustrating everyday inflation impacts.

questions.question: What is the current U.S. federal minimum wage (in cents per hour)?
questions.hint: It hasn't changed since 2009 - same year as Bitcoin's genesis block
questions.explanation: $7.25/hour (725 cents) has been the federal minimum wage since 2009, showing how fiat wages stagnate while prices rise.

questions.question: Approximately how many billion dollars is the market cap of gold (in thousands of billions)?
questions.hint: Think 10-15 trillion dollars
questions.explanation: Gold's market cap is approximately $12-13 trillion. Bitcoin aims to compete with this as a store of value.

questions.question: What was the year of 'The Black Swan' book publication by Nassim Taleb?
questions.hint: Mid-2000s, right before the financial crisis
questions.explanation: Taleb's 'The Black Swan' was published in 2007, presciently before the 2008 financial crisis that inspired Bitcoin.

questions.question: What is the most common HTTP status code for 'Not Found'?
questions.hint: It's a famous error code everyone has seen
questions.explanation: HTTP 404 means 'Not Found' - a page doesn't exist. It's internet culture at this point.

questions.question: How many first-generation Pokémon exist?
questions.hint: Gotta catch 'em all! It's on the orange pill sign.
questions.explanation: There are 151 original Pokémon in Generation 1 (Red/Blue/Yellow), a cultural touchstone for millennials.

questions.question: In what year was the first iPhone released?
questions.hint: Late 2000s - revolutionized mobile computing
questions.explanation: The iPhone launched in 2007, creating the smartphone era and enabling mobile Bitcoin wallets.

questions.question: What is the standard port number for HTTP web traffic?
questions.hint: It's a two-digit number - super common
questions.explanation: Port 80 is the default for HTTP (unencrypted web traffic). HTTPS uses 443.

questions.question: How many bits are in an IPv4 address?
questions.hint: It's a multiple of 8, creates the familiar 4-part format
questions.explanation: IPv4 addresses are 32 bits (4 bytes), giving 4.3 billion possible addresses - not enough for Bitcoin's global scale!

questions.question: What is the standard port number for HTTPS encrypted web traffic?
questions.hint: It's on the green pill sign - think secure connections
questions.explanation: Port 443 is the standard for HTTPS (encrypted web traffic). Always check for HTTPS when entering wallet info!

questions.question: In what year was Facebook (now Meta) founded?
questions.hint: Mid-2000s at Harvard
questions.explanation: Facebook launched in 2004, creating the social media era and centralized data collection Bitcoin resists.

questions.question: What is the average temperature of the human body in Fahrenheit?
questions.hint: Normal body temp - everyone should know this
questions.explanation: Normal human body temperature is 98.6°F (37°C). Health is wealth, and Bitcoin is financial health!

questions.question: At what temperature (Fahrenheit) does water boil at sea level?
questions.hint: A round number everyone learns in school
questions.explanation: Water boils at 212°F (100°C) at sea level. Basic science, like Bitcoin's fixed supply, is immutable.

questions.question: How many watts does a typical modern refrigerator use (average)?
questions.hint: Think 100-200 watts continuous
questions.explanation: Modern refrigerators use approximately 100-200 watts on average. Understanding power consumption helps evaluate Bitcoin mining energy use.

questions.question: How many days are in a non-leap year?
questions.hint: Basic calendar knowledge
questions.explanation: 365 days in a standard year. Bitcoin's supply schedule is even more predictable than Earth's orbit!

questions.question: What is the typical American household's average monthly electricity bill (in dollars)?
questions.hint: Think $100-$150 range
questions.explanation: The average U.S. household electricity bill is approximately $110-$140/month, varying by region and usage.

questions.question: How many feet above sea level is Denver, Colorado (approximately)?
questions.hint: It's called the 'Mile High City' - how many feet in a mile?
questions.explanation: Denver sits at approximately 5,280 feet (exactly one mile) above sea level, hence 'Mile High City.'

questions.question: What is the speed of light (in thousands of kilometers per second)?
questions.hint: Just under 300,000 km/s
questions.explanation: Light travels at approximately 299,792 km/s (about 300,000). Bitcoin transactions travel at the speed of the internet, not light!

questions.question: What is 'the answer to the ultimate question of life, the universe, and everything' from Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy?
questions.hint: It's on the orange pill sign - a famous sci-fi reference
questions.explanation: 42 is the answer in Douglas Adams' 'Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy' - a cultural touchstone for geeks worldwide, including Bitcoiners.

questions.question: What temperature (in Fahrenheit) is the title of Ray Bradbury's famous book about censorship?
questions.hint: It's the temperature at which paper burns - on the orange pill sign
questions.explanation: 'Fahrenheit 451' warns about censorship and information control - themes Bitcoin addresses through uncensorable transactions.

questions.question: What is the 4th perfect number (a number whose divisors sum to itself)?
questions.hint: It's on the green pill sign - it's over 8,000!
questions.explanation: 8128 is the 4th perfect number: 1+2+4+8+16+32+64+127+254+508+1016+2032+4064 = 8128. Mathematical perfection, like Bitcoin's code.

questions.question: What power level is Goku famously over in Dragon Ball Z?
questions.hint: It's over... (finish the meme)
questions.explanation: 'It's over 9000!' is one of the most famous anime memes. Bitcoin's power level is also over 9000.

questions.question: In what year was the song 'Boom Boom Pow' by Black Eyed Peas released?
questions.hint: Late 2000s - year is literally in the lyrics
questions.explanation: 'Boom Boom Pow' dropped in 2009 - same year as Bitcoin's genesis block. 'Gotta get that boom boom pow!'

questions.question: How many players are on a basketball team on the court at one time?
questions.hint: Basic sports knowledge
questions.explanation: 5 players per team on the court. Teamwork makes the dream work - like Bitcoin's decentralized network.

questions.question: What is Nikola Tesla's famous sacred number sequence (just the middle number)?
questions.hint: 3, 6, 9 - which is in the middle?
questions.explanation: Tesla believed 3, 6, and 9 were sacred numbers holding the key to the universe. 369 is on the orange pill sign.
